Description: Body sherd of Chian Grand Style pottery light chalice; white slip; interior: glazed streaky black; part of lotus flower and pomegranate chain (in added red and white), above white line; exterior: painted decoration consisting of raised light brown coloured left hand of a male dancer, to right.
Curator's comments: The sherd joins British Museum 1888,0601.507. According to Williams, the figure was probably a buttock-padded dancer and probably belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1888,0601.502, 1888,0601.515 and 1888,0601.516. Williams argues that the image portrayed on the chalice was perhaps the representation of komos activities that took place in Chios. The buttock pads exaggerated the dancers’ bottoms. The sakkos worn by many of these komasts as well as the earrings suggest the dancers, who were male, were practicing a form of transvestism. If so, these Chians dancers were precursors of the magodoi or performers who wore women’s clothing, made lewd gestures and performed as female and drunk characters. The gestures of the dancers on the chalices are limited and consist of holding pomegranates, tambourines (or wreaths) and snapping fingers. Williams, D. ‘Aigina, Aphaia-Tempel 5. The pottery from Chios’, Archäologischer Anzeiger 1983.
